TYRANT.deftext:
a dictator, cruel ruler

A TYRANT is a person who seizes power in a country and then proceeds to rule in a very cruel and unfair way. A TYRANT is a dictator, a person whose word is law.

“The TYRANT grew wealthy by placing taxes on just about everything.”

“The people hated the TYRANT who ruled over them in such a cruel fashion.”

The word TYRANT is also used about any person who rules others unfairly.

“He thinks his mother is a TYRANT just because she won’t let him drive at night.”

Other forms of the word: TYRANNICAL, adj. TYRANNIZE, v. TYRANNY, n.

RESIDE.deftext:
to live, dwell

To RESIDE in a place is to live there, to have your home there.

“He RESIDES in Florida now.”

“She RESIDES in one state, but works in another.”

A RESIDENCE is a place where someone lives, a home, especially a large or dignified one.

“Their RESIDENCE is the brick house at the end of the street.”

It is also the act of RESIDING.

“After years of living in a house we took up RESIDENCE in an apartment.”

Other forms of the word: RESIDENCE, n. RESIDENTIAL, adj.

IMMORTAL.deftext:
undying, deathless, lasting forever

The Latin word mors means death. It is the source of the words mortal and mortality. Someone or something that is IMMORTAL will not die, will last forever. The word is usually applied to people’s souls or to their actions and achievements.

“Patrick Henry said those IMMORTAL words, ‘Give me liberty or give me death!’”

“Everyone should read Shakespeare’s IMMORTAL plays.”

To IMMORTALIZE something is to make it last or be remembered forever.

“Longfellow’s poem IMMORTALIZED Paul Revere’s ride.”

Other forms of the word: IMMORTALITY, n. IMMORTALIZE, v.
suffix: See in-2 under Prefixes and -al under Suffixes.

PACT.deftext:
an agreement, compact

A PACT is an agreement between persons or groups.

“We made a PACT that neither of us would tell the secret.”

PACT is often used when referring to agreements or treaties between countries.

“The two nations signed a PACT that each would help the other in time of war.”

“The PACT limited the size of each nation’s army.”

RECOIL.deftext:
to draw back, move backward, shrink

To RECOIL is to draw back or jump back, especially because of fear, horror, or disgust.

“I RECOILED when he offered to let me hold the spider.”

RECOIL does not always suggest an actual physical movement. You can RECOIL inwardly from something as well.

“They RECOILED in horror from the idea of visiting the haunted house.”

RECOIL is also used with regard to a gun kicking back when it is fired.

“He steadied himself so that he wouldn’t be knocked over when the rifle RECOILED.”

INFLICT.deftext:
to lay on, impose

To INFLICT something is to cause it to be suffered. You always INFLICT something unpleasant or painful, like damage or physical punishment.

“The bomb INFLICTED serious damage on the city.”

“The bully INFLICTED a terrible beating on him.”

Other forms of the word: INFLICTION, n.

Usage: INFLICT is usually used with on: to INFLICT something on someone.

INTENTION.deftext:
purpose, aim

INTEND means “to have in mind as something to be done.”

“I INTEND to go to the beach this summer.”

An INTENTION is something that you have in mind that you want to do, a purpose or goal.

“I have no INTENTION of watching television tonight.”

“His INTENTIONS were good, but he didn’t carry them out.”

“She announced her INTENTION to run for mayor in the next election.”

Many people think an INTENTION is a wish. The words are close in meaning, but INTENTION suggests a much stronger determination to do something. Anyone can wish to be famous, for example; but if it is your INTENTION, you are going to work hard to see that it happens.

Other forms of the word: INTEND, v. INTENTIONAL, adj.

OBLIGATION.deftext:
a duty, responsibility

An OBLIGATION is something that you must do (or not do). It is a duty that results from a law, a custom, a promise, or the like.

“He felt he had an OBLIGATION to help those less fortunate than he was.”

“You have an OBLIGATION to pay back the money I lent you.”

“He carried out his OBLIGATION to the company, and then felt he didn’t have to do anything more.”

“There is no OBLIGATION to buy anything. We just want you to try our product for ten days.”

Other forms of the word: OBLIGE, v.

PORTRAY.deftext:
to picture, describe, represent

To PORTRAY means “to make a picture of” someone or something. You can PORTRAY by painting.

“He PORTRAYED the queen as a beautiful young woman in the painting.”

Or you can PORTRAY in words.

“The king is PORTRAYED as a villain in this novel.”

Actors PORTRAY characters on stage; that is, they present a picture of the characters.

“She PORTRAYED Hamlet’s mother in the play.”

A PORTRAIT is a picture, particularly a painting of a person.

“Whistler painted a famous PORTRAIT of his mother.”

The most commonly chosen wrong answer in the Pretest item is deceive, probably because of confusion with betray.

Other forms of the word: PORTRAIT, n.

STATIONARY.deftext:
unmoving, fixed in position

STATIONARY is related to the word STATION. Both come from a Latin word meaning to stand. One meaning of STATION is “a place where something or someone stands.”

“A guard should never leave his STATION.”

Something that is STATIONARY stands in one place; it cannot or does not move.

“Nothing was moving on the whole street. All the cars were STATIONARY.”

“These heavy machines are STATIONARY; once they are set in place they can’t be moved.”

RENOVATE.deftext:
to restore, renew, revive

The nov part of the word comes from the Latin word for new, also the source of the words novel and novelty. To RENOVATE something is to make it new again. The word is usually applied to the restoring and repairing of old buildings so that they are like new again.

“We would like to RENOVATE our apartment. We want to fix it up completely.”

“The kitchen was old-fashioned and had to be RENOVATED before they could sell the house.”

Many people think RENOVATE means tear down, which means just about the opposite.

Other forms of the word: RENOVATION, n.
suffix: See re- under Prefixes and -ate1 under Suffixes.

SKETCHY.deftext:
incomplete, like a SKETCH, without details

A SKETCH is an outline of something, a quick drawing, not the complete picture. Anything that is SKETCHY is like a SKETCH. It is incomplete, lacking in detail. The word is used especially about understanding or information that is only vague and incomplete.

“Her understanding of algebra is somewhat SKETCHY.”

“He could only give us SKETCHY directions on how to get there.”

“We had only a SKETCHY idea of what the movie was supposed to be about.”

Other forms of the word: SKETCH, n., v.

TOPPLE.deftext:
to fall, fall over; to push over, overturn

To TOPPLE is to fall over, especially from being too heavy on top.

“He piled the bricks so high that the stack TOPPLED.”

“The strong winds finally caused the tree to TOPPLE with a crash.”

To TOPPLE something is to push it over or overturn it.

“The mean boys TOPPLED the snowman we had just finished.”

The word is often used about the overthrowing of someone in a position of authority.

“The rebels TOPPLED the dictator’s government.”

YEARN.deftext:
to long, pine

To YEARN for something is to desire it strongly, usually with an eager or tender kind of feeling.

“He YEARNED for one last chance to see his native land.”

“Billy YEARNED to be a famous baseball player.”

“The prisoner YEARNED to be free.”

YEARNING is the noun from YEARN. A YEARNING is a longing or a strong desire.

“She felt a deep YEARNING to help humanity.”

“He never satisfied his YEARNING for more money.”

Other forms of the word: YEARNING, n.

DRAB.deftext:
dull, monotonous, uninteresting, colorless

Something that is DRAB is uninteresting, colorless, lifeless.

“His wife’s lovely personality lent color to his otherwise DRAB existence.”

The word DRAB is also used in a more specific sense to describe a dull, muddy brown or gray color.

“The DRAB color scheme of the room made it lifeless and uninviting.”

Many people think DRAB means filthy. Something may be colorless and dull, however, and still be perfectly clean.

questions.prompt: Do people often RESIDE in factories?
Can countries make PACTS with one another?
Do you like something that makes you RECOIL?
Is it possible to INFLICT damage on a car if you hit it with a hammer?
Does an INTENTION have to do with the future?
Do parents have an OBLIGATION to care for their children?
Can you PORTRAY a person in a story?
Is a jet STATIONARY when it is in the air?
Would a brand new building have been RENOVATED?
Would most people want to go to a doctor who has a SKETCHY knowledge of medicine?
Would it be difficult to TOPPLE a mountain?
Do most people YEARN for happiness?
At work he was mild and kind, but at home he was an unjust TYRANT to his children.
After living in a cottage all summer, he returned to his permanent RESIDENCE.
Mona Lisa was IMMORTALIZED in Leonardo Da Vinci's painting.
The heavy PACT was almost impossible to carry.
He RECOILED at the thought of eating raw oysters.
I have never been so INFLICTED in my life as when I heard that we had won the lottery.
I INTEND to go to Europe some day, no matter how much it costs.
I have no OBLIGATION to help you do your homework.
The actor PORTRAYED a character who loved money more than anything else.
We bolted the wobbly table to the wall so that it would remain STATIONARY.
The landlord called in a wrecking crew to RENOVATE the building.
Her SKETCHY voice was very unpleasant to listen to.
The ice cream was TOPPLED with a chocolate sauce.
Mrs. Jones YEARNED to see her children.
She bought new curtains to brighten up the DRAB room.
